multiple-choice.question: What happened to the kudzu vine in its native east Asia?

options.label: A
options.text: It grew uncontrollably and outcompeted native organisms.

options.label: B
options.text: It was eaten by various insects and died off during the cold winters.

options.label: C
options.text: It was introduced to the southeastern United States for porch decoration and cattle feed.

options.label: D
options.text: It was banned by the government due to its invasive nature.

multiple-choice.question: What is causing a significant reduction in the populations of organisms in Florida's Everglades?

options.label: B
options.text: The presence of invasive species, such as Burmese pythons.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of a limiting factor in an ecosystem?

options.label: A
options.text: The presence of a specific species.

options.label: B
options.text: The absence of a specific species.

options.label: C
options.text: Environmental conditions that restrict the size or range of a species.

multiple-choice.question: What can happen to an ecosystem when a non-native organism is introduced?

options.label: D
options.text: The ecosystem's balance is disrupted, and the new organism out-competes native organisms for resources.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of an invasive species that was introduced by humans?

options.label: A
options.text: The zebra mussel, which was accidentally brought to Lake Erie by cargo ships.

options.label: B
options.text: The Burmese python, which was released by pet owners in Florida's Everglades.

options.label: C
options.text: The European rabbit, which was introduced to Australia for hunting purposes.

multiple-choice.question: What can be done to prevent the introduction of invasive species?

options.label: A
options.text: Governments can ban the imports of certain organisms.

options.label: B
options.text: People can migrate around the world without bringing their plants and animals along.

options.label: C
options.text: The transport of plants and animals can be monitored closely.

multiple-choice.question: Are humans an invasive species?

options.label: A
options.text: Yes, we are an invasive species that has covered most of the world.

options.label: B
options.text: No, we are not an invasive species.

options.label: C
options.text: Maybe, we are a group of primates who emerged from Africa.

title: Can plants talk to each other? - Richard Karban

multiple-choice.question: How do plants typically communicate with each other?

options.label: A
options.text: Through complex sensory or nervous systems.

options.label: B
options.text: Through chemical signals in response to their environments.

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary method of communication between plants in the soil?

options.label: B
options.text: Through fungal filaments that form extensive networks.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of a plant releasing volatile chemicals when its leaves get damaged?

options.label: A
options.text: To attract predators to attack the plant.

options.label: B
options.text: To warn neighboring plants of the attack.

options.label: C
options.text: To increase its own internal chemistry.

options.label: D
options.text: To decrease its own internal chemistry.

multiple-choice.question: How do different plants convey warning signals to each other?
What is the significance of the similarity between the chemical fingerprints of two plants?

options.label: A
options.text: The more similar they are, the less effectively they can communicate.

options.label: B
options.text: The more similar they are, the more fluently they can communicate.

options.label: C
options.text: The more similar they are, the less they can communicate at all.

options.label: D
options.text: The more similar they are, the more they can communicate with other species.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of fungi in plant communication?

options.label: A
options.text: To absorb water and nutrients from the soil.

options.label: B
options.text: To form extensive networks that can connect separate plants.

options.label: C
options.text: To increase the plant's internal chemistry.

options.label: D
options.text: To decrease the plant's internal chemistry.

multiple-choice.question: How do plants respond to blight through their fungal networks?

options.label: A
options.text: By activating disease-fighting genes and enzymes.

options.label: B
options.text: By increasing production of compounds that repel aphids.

options.label: D
options.text: By decreasing production of compounds that repel aphids.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of plants being able to communicate with each other?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows them to compete more effectively for resources.

options.label: B
options.text: It allows them to cooperate more effectively for survival.

options.label: C
options.text: It allows them to communicate with other species.

options.label: D
options.text: It allows them to communicate with humans.

title: What is abstract expressionism? - Sarah Rosenthal

multiple-choice.question: What is the movement called that gets the reaction, "My cat could make that, so how is it art?"
Which artist is famous for his travestied women?
What is the name of the technique that Jackson Pollock used to create his paintings?
Why is Jackson Pollock's work considered special?

options.label: A
options.text: Because he was the only artist who could have made his paintings

options.label: B
options.text: Because his process resulted in radically flat painted surfaces

options.label: C
options.text: Because he destroyed conventions of painting that had stood for centuries

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the artist who created soak-stains?
What is the name of the movement that supposedly drew directly from the unconscious to reveal truths hidden within their minds?
Why did Jackson Pollock take the canvas off of the easel and lay it on the floor?

options.label: B
options.text: To control how the paint made contact with the surface

options.label: C
options.text: To make his paintings more accessible

options.label: D
options.text: To create a sense of chaos

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the artist who is considered a celebrity in the art world?
What is the name of the technique that involves letting the hands move automatically and would later tease out familiar figures that appeared in the scribbles?
Why did the history embedded in Abstract Expressionism reinforce a long-standing elitist aspect of art?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it destroyed conventions of painting that had stood for centuries

options.label: B
options.text: Because it elevated Jackson Pollock to the mythified status of the genius artist as hero

options.label: C
options.text: Because it made his paintings more accessible

options.label: D
options.text: Because it was a subversive act

title: The World's Roundest Object (and Why it Exists)

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the sphere made of silicon-28 atoms that the speaker is holding?
What is the purpose of the silicon sphere?

options.label: A
options.text: To redefine the kilogram as the mass of a litre of water at its densest temperature

options.label: B
options.text: To create a new unit of measurement for mass

options.label: C
options.text: To count the number of atoms in the sphere and use it to redefine Avogadro's constant

options.label: D
options.text: To measure the mass of a platinum-iridium cylinder

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the scientist who originally conceived of silicon as an element?
What is the name of the alloy used to make the International Prototype Kilogram?
What is the name of the base unit of mass in the metric system that was originally called the "grave"?
Why was the name "grave" changed to "kilogram"?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it sounded too similar to the aristocratic title "graf"

multiple-choice.question: What is the mass of a litre of water at nearly 4 degrees Celsius?
What is the name of the device used to measure the diameter of the silicon sphere?
What is the name of the constant that is being redefined using the silicon sphere?
What is the name of the approach that involves fixing Planck's constant to redefine the kilogram?

title: Why do cats act so weird? - Tony Buffington

multiple-choice.question: What is one reason why cats are entertaining to watch?

options.label: C
options.text: They exhibit strange feline behaviors, both amusing and baffling.

multiple-choice.question: What is one crucial instinctual behavior that cats have retained from their wild ancestors?

options.label: C
options.text: The ability to stalk and pounce on prey.

multiple-choice.question: Why do cats climb to high vantage points?

options.label: C
options.text: To survey their territory and spot prey.

multiple-choice.question: What is one reason why cats are opportunistic hunters?

options.label: C
options.text: They need to eat many times each day.

multiple-choice.question: Why do cats have sharp claws?
Why do cats like to reach into containers and openings?

options.label: C
options.text: To explore their environment and use the same curiosity that helped ensure the continuation of their species.

multiple-choice.question: What is one reason why cats prefer a clean and odor-free litter box?

options.label: C
options.text: To avoid giving away their location to predators.

multiple-choice.question: What is one possible reason why cats purr?
What is one reason why cats are able to thrive in their environment?

options.label: C
options.text: Because they retain many of the same instincts that allowed them to thrive in the wild for millions of years.

multiple-choice.question: What is one possible way that cats view their human companions?

options.label: A
options.text: As big, dumb, hairless cats competing with them for resources.

options.label: B
options.text: As terribly stupid predators they're able to outsmart every day.

title: Why is being scared so fun? - Margee Kerr

multiple-choice.question: Why do people often visit haunted houses in October?

options.label: B
options.text: To experience a natural high from being scared.

options.label: C
options.text: To see their friends scream and laugh.

multiple-choice.question: What happens to our bodies when a threat triggers our fight or flight response?

options.label: A
options.text: We feel pain and get tired.

options.label: B
options.text: We release chemicals that change how our brains and bodies function.

options.label: C
options.text: We shut down nonessential systems like critical thought.

multiple-choice.question: What is similar between the high-arousal state experienced during fear and other positive states like excitement and happiness?

options.label: A
options.text: The context in which they occur.

options.label: D
options.text: The brain activity associated with them.

multiple-choice.question: Why do some people love the dizziness associated with a loop-de-loop on a roller coaster, while others loathe the stomach-drop sensation of a steep roller coaster?

options.label: A
options.text: Because of individual differences in brain chemistry.

options.label: B
options.text: Because of the thrill of the ride.

options.label: C
options.text: Because of the fear of heights.

options.label: D
options.text: Because of the noise of the ride.

multiple-choice.question: What is a result of doing things that we're afraid of?
What is the hormone released during fight or flight that aids in the feeling of closeness to those we're with?
Why do we want to repeat experiences that trigger a strong emotional reaction?
What is the result of experiencing a natural high from being scared in a safe place?

options.label: A
options.text: A sense of fear and anxiety.

multiple-choice.question: Why do people on roller coasters often go from screaming to laughing within moments?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are relieved that the ride is over.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are experiencing a natural high from being scared.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are bored with the ride.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are scared of heights.

multiple-choice.question: What is the evolutionary adaptation that allows those who have the right balance of bravery and wit to know when to push through fear and when to retreat to be rewarded with survival, new food, and new lands?

options.label: D
options.text: The ability to balance bravery and wit.

title: The backwards brain bicycle: un-doing understanding

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea of the video?

options.label: A
options.text: Destin Sandlin's experiment to learn how to ride a normal bike again.

options.label: B
options.text: Destin Sandlin's experiment to learn how to ride a backwards bike.

options.label: C
options.text: Destin Sandlin's experiment to prove that knowledge is not understanding.

options.label: D
options.text: Destin Sandlin's experiment to show that children have more neural plasticity than adults.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the bike that Destin Sandlin is trying to ride?

options.label: D
options.text: A bicycle with a special algorithm.

multiple-choice.question: What did Destin Sandlin learn from his experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: That knowledge is equal to understanding.

options.label: B
options.text: That children have less neural plasticity than adults.

options.label: D
options.text: That knowledge does not equal understanding, and that truth is truth.

multiple-choice.question: What did Destin Sandlin's son learn from the experiment?

options.label: A
options.text: That he could not ride a backwards bike.

options.label: B
options.text: That he could ride a normal bike in 8 months.

options.label: C
options.text: That he had more neural plasticity than his father.

options.label: D
options.text: That he could ride a backwards bike in 2 weeks.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main message of the video?

options.label: C
options.text: That children have more neural plasticity than adults.

options.label: D
options.text: That knowledge does not equal understanding, and that truth is truth.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the astronaut that Destin Sandlin recommends?
What is the name of the book that Destin Sandlin recommends?

options.label: A
options.text: An Astronaut's Guide to Life on Earth.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the website where you can download a free audio book?
What is the main idea of the video's ending?

options.label: A
options.text: That Destin Sandlin is a genius.

options.label: B
options.text: That Destin Sandlin is a failure.

options.label: C
options.text: That truth is truth, and that knowledge does not equal understanding.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the person who is narrating the video?

title: The surprising reason you feel awful when you're sick - Marco A. Sotomayor

multiple-choice.question: What initially triggers the body's immune response when a pathogen like the flu virus enters the system?

options.label: A
options.text: The body's cells start to die.

options.label: B
options.text: The body's cells start to multiply.

options.label: C
options.text: The pathogen alerts the body's immune system to the infection.

options.label: D
options.text: The body's immune system is always on.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of macrophages in the body's immune response?

options.label: A
options.text: They produce cytokines to recruit more virus-busting cells.

options.label: B
options.text: They search for and destroy viruses and infected cells.

options.label: C
options.text: They release protein molecules to recruit and organize more virus-busting cells.

options.label: D
options.text: They produce antibodies to fight off infections.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of cytokines in the body's immune response?

options.label: A
options.text: They slow down the immune response.

options.label: B
options.text: They recruit and organize more virus-busting cells from the immune system.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the hypothalamus in the body's immune response?

options.label: A
options.text: It controls the body's temperature, thirst, hunger, and sleep.

options.label: B
options.text: It produces antibodies to fight off infections.

options.label: C
options.text: It produces cytokines to recruit more virus-busting cells.

options.label: D
options.text: It slows down the immune response.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the body's aches and pains during an illness?

options.label: B
options.text: To draw attention to infected cuts.

options.label: C
options.text: To make the body more comfortable.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of cytokines and prostaglandin in the body's immune response?

options.label: B
options.text: They disrupt the activity of neurotransmitters.

options.label: C
options.text: They slow down the immune response.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the body's unpleasant symptoms during an illness?

options.label: A
options.text: To make the body more comfortable.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of sleep in the body's immune response?

options.label: C
options.text: It channels more energy towards fighting infection.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of the liver in the body's immune response?

options.label: A
options.text: It produces antibodies to fight off infections.

options.label: B
options.text: It produces cytokines to recruit more virus-busting cells.

options.label: C
options.text: It takes up much of the iron in the blood.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of the body's reduced thirst during an illness?

options.label: B
options.text: To draw attention to infected cuts.

options.label: C
options.text: To diminish transmission through sneezes, coughs, vomit, or diarrhea.
